content: The "Bronzeville-Black Metropolis National Heritage Area Act" establishes the Heritage Area, defines key terms, and outlines the management plan under the Secretary of the Interior for the State of Illinois. The Bronzeville-Black Metropolis National Heritage Area is established in Chicago, Illinois, with specific boundaries outlined from 18th Street to 67th Street, encompassing key landmarks and historical sites. The Bronzeville-Black Metropolis National Heritage Area in Chicago, Illinois extends from 55th Street to 71st Street, covering landmarks and historical sites. The boundaries range from State Street to the Metra Railroad tracks. The local coordinating entity is designated in the Bronzeville-Black Metropolis National Heritage Area in Chicago, Illinois. The Black Metropolis National Heritage Area Commission is the local coordinating entity for the Heritage Area. It has the authority to use Federal funds for various purposes such as preparing reports, making grants, entering into agreements, hiring staff, and obtaining funds from any source. The local coordinating entity for the Black Metropolis National Heritage Area has the authority to use Federal funds for various purposes, including preparing a management plan, implementing actions, goals, and strategies, and contracting for goods and services. The management plan for the Black Metropolis National Heritage Area includes establishing interpretive exhibits, developing recreational and educational opportunities, increasing public awareness of resources, restoring historic buildings, and installing clear signs for public access. The management plan for the Black Metropolis National Heritage Area includes developing interpretive exhibits, recreational and educational opportunities, increasing public awareness, restoring historic buildings, and ensuring clear public access points. Additionally, the plan involves considering the interests of various stakeholders, conducting regular public meetings, and submitting annual reports on accomplishments and finances. The local coordinating entity must disclose entities receiving grants, provide records for audit of Federal and matching funds expenditures, and ensure receiving organizations make their expenditure records available for audit. SEC. 5. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The local coordinating entity must submit a management plan to the Secretary within 3 years of funds being available for the Heritage Area. The plan should include policies, strategies, and funding sources for conservation, consider existing plans, and inventory resources to be preserved. The local coordinating entity must submit a management plan to the Secretary within 3 years of funds being available for the Heritage Area. The plan should include an analysis of ways to coordinate Federal, State, and local programs, and recommendations for the role of the National Park Service in the Heritage Area. If the plan is not submitted on time, the entity may not receive additional funding until it is submitted. The Secretary must approve or disapprove the management plan within 180 days of submission. The local coordinating entity must submit a management plan to the Secretary for approval. The Secretary considers various factors, including the entity's representation of diverse interests in the Heritage Area, public and governmental involvement in plan preparation, and resource protection and interpretation. The management plan must adequately protect natural, historic, and cultural resources of the Heritage Area. If the Secretary disapproves the plan, they must provide reasons in writing to the local coordinating entity. The Secretary must approve or disapprove a revised management plan within 180 days of submission. Substantial amendments to the plan must also be approved by the Secretary before any changes can be implemented using funds appropriated under the Act. SEC. 6. RELATIONSHIP TO OTHER FEDERAL AGENCIES. The Act does not affect a Federal agency's authority to provide assistance under other laws. Federal agencies planning activities impacting the Heritage Area should consult with the Secretary and local entity. The Act does not change laws authorizing Federal land management or limit a land manager's discretion within the Heritage Area. SEC. 7. PRIVATE PROPERTY AND REGULATORY PROTECTIONS. The Act does not limit property owners' rights, including the right to not participate in Heritage Area activities, require public access to their property, change existing land use regulations, or claim water rights. The Heritage Area Act does not limit property owners' rights, including the right to not participate in activities or claim water rights. It also does not diminish the State's authority to manage fish and wildlife or create liability for private property owners regarding injuries on their property. SEC. 8. EVALUATION; REPORT. The Secretary must conduct an evaluation of the Heritage Area's accomplishments and prepare a report before Federal funding ends. The evaluation includes assessing the local entity's progress, analyzing investments, and reviewing the management structure. The Secretary will review the management structure, partnership relationships, and funding of the Heritage Area to identify critical components for sustainability. A report will be prepared with recommendations for the future role of the National Park Service, including an analysis of ways to reduce or eliminate Federal funding if reauthorization is recommended. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress, including the Senate's Committee on Energy and Natural Resources and the House's Committee on Natural Resources, upon completion of a review of the Heritage Area's management structure, partnership relationships, and funding. The report will contain recommendations for the future role of the National Park Service, with an analysis on reducing or eliminating Federal funding if reauthorization is suggested. Authorization of Appropriations: $10,000,000 authorized for the Act, with a limit of $1,000,000 per fiscal year. Cost-sharing requirement: Federal share not to exceed 50%. Termination of Authority: Secretary's financial assistance authority ends 15 years after enactment of the Act.
